dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the DISSOLVE of the words the stock shot comes to li with a carriage coming toward the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SPOT -- Down the lonely, almost deserted street come cab drawn by a bony white horse.  This black and sepulchr vehicle passes through the long shadows and sharp gleams the late afternoon sun.  On the box, bunched over, almost lost in the folds of his triple-caped overcoat and with a battered beaver on his hand, is the cabman.  The horse pl along, his hoof beats echoing with a hollow sound in the narrow street.  At the corner the vehicle turns left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black cab drawn by the white horse goes slowly past a little cemetery.  The driver turns his head and looks dow he goes past. From his ANGLE, but not a MOVING SHOT, a pleasant little graveyard with mossy gravestones; old turf making a spot green between the gray walls of the kirk and the blank st wall of a large building. Seated on a table stone is young Donald Fettes, a poor medical student, dressed in worn neat clothing with only woolen scarf about his neck for warmth.  He sits in such scanty sunlight as he can find, munching on a cold bannoc and washing it down with thin ale from a round stone bott MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes.  In the closer view it can be that he is looking at a small Cairn terrier who lies moro guarding a newly-made grave.  The dog, with his head down between his forepaws, occasionally glances over apprehensively at the young student.  Fettes takes a bit his bannock between his thumb and forefinger and leans forward toward the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, -- here's a bit of something for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog does not stir.  Fettes leans further forward almo putting the morsel of food to the dog's nose.  The dog gr savagely.  Fettes draws back. FETTES (cont'd) Now, now, laddie -- I only wanted to be friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is at this moment that a shadow falls athwart him and looms up in the afternoon sunlight against the wall behin him.  He looks up. ANOTHER ANGLE -- Fettes looking over as Mrs. MacBride, a plump, motherly woman of middle-age, with a Tartan shawl her head and carrying a pannikin of water and a bone with some meat on it, comes through the gate.  She crosses ove the little dog, puts the water before him and starts shredding little pieces of meat from the bone to feed him The dog laps avidly at the water, then gratefully takes t morsels of meat she gives him. MED. FULL SHOT -- Fettes and Mrs. MacBride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll not leave the grave -- not since Wednesday last when we buried the lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son, ma'am?  He must have been a fine boy for the wee dog to love him so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. MacBride nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great, kind lad, he was -- gentle with all things like Robbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, sighs and then goes on. MRS. MACBRIDE (cont'd) Now I can't get the dog to leave, here.  Perhaps it is for the best.  I've not money enough to afford a grave watcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking about) Not much danger here, ma'am, I wouldn't think -- right here in the heart of Edinburgh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're uncommon bold, the grave robbers -- and the daft doctors who drive them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little uncomfortable; feeling he has to make the admission) I'm by way of being a medical myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A student.  I'm studying under Dr. MacFarlane -- that is, I've been studying until today --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to get up.  At this moment in the street can be heard the clop-clop of a horse's hoofs and the rattle of wheels on the cobblestones.  On the ground and gravestone appears and passes the monstrous shadow of a horse and ca angular and distorted, the driver's shadow hunched and ev now going from left to right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT -- a typical street scene of the time.  A dog c drawn by a smart tandem passes.  It is driven by a young of the period; top-hatted, dandified, his whip held at a so angle.  On the sidewalk, a group of small boys follow recruiting sergeant of the Seaforth Highlanders.  A drumm walks at his heels.  He stops at a wooden "Charlie", the rough police booth of that day, and begins to tack up his posters.  The boys crowd around to watch.  One of them ba up to a little trundle cart and surreptitiously filches a piece of the shortbread being sold from this portable sto At the other side of the "Charlie" stands a street singer beautiful girl of about nineteen, dressed in ragged Highl plaid.  She is singing an old border ballad about two cro who sit waiting to pick the dead eyes out of a fallen kni A shepherd, crook in hand, and faithfully attended by two handsome collies, stops a moment to hear her song, drops coppers into the begging bowl she holds in her hands, the passes on. Through the consonance of the street singer's song comes dissonant beat of a horse's hoofs, the racking clatter of iron-shod wheels and then between the singer and the CAME there passes, very close, the white horse and the black c As it blocks her out of the scene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT -- Before the imposing edifice which houses Dr. MacFarlane's living quarters as well as his school of anatomy, the cab, drawn by the white horse, pulls up.  Th driver begins to alight from the box.  He climbs down, an starts for the cab door. CLOSE SHOT -- Gray as he opens the door.  Gray is a man o middle years with keen, darting eyes set in a face lined furrowed by an evil life.  The quick play of his features he talks or smiles can form a moving and deceptive mask. that now as he opens the door, smiling, to help his passengers alight, his face is cringing with good humor a servility. From the cab steps a young and lovely woman dressed in becoming widow's weeds.  This is Mrs. Marsh.  She reaches sidewalk, turns back for the other occupant of the cab. is a little girl of about eight, dressed in a flower-spri Kate Greenway gown and a poke bonnet to match.  Gray forestalls her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches his hat respectfully, reaches in and brings ou tiny wheel-chair, which he sets down.  He reaches in agai and takes the child up in his arms. GRAY (cont'd) (as he picks her up) Come, little miss.  Cabman Gray'll carry you safe enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the child in his arms he starts toward his horse's h talking as he goes. GRAY (cont'd) Give my horse a pat.  He knows every little girl in Edinburgh.  Some day when you're runnin' and playin' in the street he'll nicker at ye as we go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- The horse, Gray, and the little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't run and play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten that, lassie.  All the more reason for Friend here bidding you a good-day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina smiles and pats the horse's nose. ANOTHER ANGLE -- Featuring Mrs. Marsh as she smiles watch Gray and the child.  He turns back toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind carrying her up the steps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh reaches for the wheel-chair. FULL SHOT -- Mrs. Marsh takes the wheel-chair up the two steps.  Gray follows carrying the child.  He sets the chi tenderly in the wheel-chair, smiling as he does so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in your own wee cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime, Mrs. Marsh has fumbled through her purse change.  She hands this to Gray.  He takes the money from right hand, then removes his hat with his left hand, bobs forelock with the right in a series of obsequious gesture

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank ye, ma'am.  Thank ye. (to Georgina) You watch sharp, little miss for my horse to give you a "hello".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- Georgina looking at Gray with great pleased eyes.  This has made a definite impression on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh has used the door knocker.  Now in response th door is opened by a handsome woman of thirty-five, Meg Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to see Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg gives Mrs. Marsh a quick look and then turns to look Gray.  A glance passes between them; a glance which tells previous acquaintance, yet neither speaks.  He turns and down the steps.  Silently, Meg opens the door and allows Marsh to push Georgina's wheel chair through into the hal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina's wheel chair is pushed into this gloomy and forbidding entry.  Meg closes the door behind them, then without further word, strides down the hall.  Mrs. Marsh the little girl wait and look around. CLOSE SHOT -- Georgina.  With great wide eyes the child l around at the antlered stag head, the cruel-looking walki sticks in the umbrella stand and the light-footed Mercury with caduceus upraised.  The caduceus throws its patterne shadow across the child's face. CLOSE TWO SHOT -- Georgina and Mrs. Marsh.  Mrs. Marsh se the fright in the child's face and reassuringly pats her shoulder.  There is the sound of a door opening and they look off in that direction. MED. FULL SHOT -- The doorway to the sitting room, SHOOTI PAST Georgina and her mother.  Framed in this doorway is tall, robust figure of Dr. Douglas MacFarlane, a man in t prime of life, dressed with almost flamboyant foppishness carrying himself with the assurance that the world is not only his oyster, but that he has it pinned on a fork and swallow it and digest it with pleasure. THREE SHOT -- Georgina, Mrs. Marsh and Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Dr. MacFarlane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He half-bows in acknowledgment. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) I'm Mrs. Marsh -- this is my daughter -- Georgina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fumbles in her reticule and pulls forth an unsealed letter which she passes to the doctor. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) Dr. Maximillian of Leyden asked me to present this to you.  He thought you might examine my little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While she is speaking, Dr. MacFarlane has opened the miss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he reads) Maximillian -- a very famous colleague of mine.  I'm delighted to honor his request.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With an expansive gesture he points to a door.  Mrs. Mars pushes the wheel chair toward the living room door. DOLLY SHOT -- the entrance to the sitting room. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (over the child's head to Mrs. Marsh) Born paralyzed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girl shrinks from him at the bluntness of this question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although it is late afternoon the lamps have been lit in part of the house.  Mrs. Marsh wheels the chair into the middle of the room and then stands to one side so that Dr MacFarlane can examine the child.  Meg Cameron stands by window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the paralysis immediate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Doctor.  She seemed to get better, then about six months later she began to complain of pain in her back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long after that was the paralysis complete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any attacks of pain since?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is her pain sporadic or constant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It comes at intervals.  They used to be months apart -- but they've been growing more frequent -- (catch in her voice) much more frequent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (directly to Georgina) See here, child, when you have this pain in your back, where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (setting her jaw) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point to where it hurts.  You can at least do that, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily to Mrs. Marsh) This is useless, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the sentence unfinished and goes toward the cen of the room.  Mrs. Marsh leans down beside the chair. TWO SHOT -- Mrs. Marsh and Georgina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, darling, don't be so stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina darts a glance in MacFarlane's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Mother -- he frightens me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT -- the door in the background.  There is a soft rap at the door and then almost immediately it opens Fettes comes in.  He looks about, sees the doctor busily engaged with a beautiful young woman and a sick child.  H embarrassed and tries to withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Dr. MacFarlane --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, boy -- come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes closes the door behind him and stands rather shyly not knowing what to do or say. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Perhaps you can do something with this young lady.  I can't get an aye, yes, or no out of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting) But, Doctor, I only wanted to speak to you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Come -- it's a chance to try out your bedside manner, Fettes.  Take a look at the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes walks up shyly to the child. TWO SHOT -- Fettes and Georgina.  Fettes stands abashed a awkward before the clear-eyed glance of the little invali He smiles at her.  The child smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a doctor, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be a good doctor.  I know all about doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a nice chair you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes it.  It rolls a little. FETTES (cont'd) Useful, too.  Where did you get it?  It isn't English, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying him) What you really want to ask me is about my back, isn't it -- about where it hurts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans forward and reaches around with one hand. GEORGINA (cont'd) It's sort of all around here -- then down my legs -- it aches as if I had been walking an awfully long way -- (looking up at Fettes) That's funny, isn't it -- because I can't walk at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind very much if I lifted you -- (pointing to a table in the other room) -- onto that table in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds out her arms to him.  Fettes lifts her up and carries her into the other room. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal Mrs. Marsh and MacFarlane watching Fettes and the child.  They stand in the f.g. talking together while in the other room Fettes puts the child down on her stomach, opens her dress and examines h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Child seems to take to the lad.  What sort of an accident was it, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carriage overturned.  My husband was killed and Georgina was hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling from the other room) Dr. MacFarlane --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Marsh) Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides forward.  Mrs. Marsh remains where she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane comes into the scene, bends over and examines little girl's back.  He feels the spine with first one ha then the other.  He nods to Fettes and turns away.  Fette begins to button up the little girl's dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane is walking back to where Mrs. Marsh stands.  I the b.g. Fettes can be seen as he buttons up the little girl's dress, picks her up in his arms and brings her bac the wheel chair.  MacFarlane comes over to Mrs. Marsh. TRUCKING SHOT of MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg, give Fettes a hand there -- help him wheel the little girl into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to Mrs. Marsh. TWO SHOT -- Mrs. Marsh and MacFarlane.  She is looking at anxiously; waiting to hear his verdict.  He glances at Dr Maximillian's letter before speaking. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (tapping the letter in his hand) It seems that Dr. Maximillian is right.  The violence of the accident must have disturbed the tissues and caused a traumatic tumor -- a sort of growth that presses against the nerve centers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But can anything be done for her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps -- a delicate operation -- an operation which has never been performed -- but it could be performed.  I'm sure it could be -- I could incise the columna dorsi --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is quite excited as he speaks, almost as if challengin himself.  Mrs.  Marsh's interruption is ill-timed.  It st him in full tide of self-persuasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) And you will try -- you will operate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane.  He is silent; thinking. MED. FULL SHOT.  MacFarlane silently turns away from Mrs. Marsh and goes to his desk.  Having reached it, he turns faces her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not I, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts toward him impulsively as if to plead with him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Doctor, in Leyden -- in Paris  - wherever I've taken Georgina -- they've mentioned your name.  I've come to think of you as our only hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane looks at her, takes a step closer to her and speaks very sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, Madame, if I were only a doctor, I would undertake this operation at once.  But I'm more dominie than doctor -- I've a school to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Doctor, surely in a case like this -- a child -- a little child who can never walk or run --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I regret it, Ma'am, but I have the responsibility of training thirty other doctors to attend a thousand children like your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing I can say for one small child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not heartless, Ma'am.  I have every sympathy for you and for the little girl, but if I were to consent to every operation brought to me, I'd have no time for teaching -- and that's a great responsibility upon me, Ma'am -- a great responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the door.  He bows in dismissal, and Mr Marsh exits.  As she leaves, Fettes passes her coming fro the hallway. MED. CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane as he turns back into the r MACFARLANE (cont'd) (to Fettes) Well, Fettes -- what was it you wanted to see me about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. TWO SHOT -- Fettes and MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) I'm afraid I'll have to give up medicine, Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (booming) You're made for a doctor, young man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I have to, sir.  You see, my father is vicar at Thrums -- it's a small parish -- not much of a living --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after thinking this over a moment; very sincerely) You're too good a man, Fettes -- I'll not let you quit. (with a sudden thought) I'll make an assistant of you -- that'll pay your keep and your tuition, too --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought only the best students were made assistants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? And are you not a good student?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting the idea) But Richardson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richardson is a fine student.  He's got a glib tongue, but you'll be a better doctor, Fettes.  Come along now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He links his arm through Fettes' and starts toward the do leading to the stairs. MACFARLANE (cont'd) -- let's get to the anatomy room -- I'll explain your new duties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the door.  Meg is standing there.  As MacFarlane and Fettes start to pass her, Meg puts her han the doctor's arm.  He pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A word with you, Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane motions Fettes to proceed into the other room. closes the door behind him. MEG (cont'd) You're not having Fettes for your assistant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why not?  He's a good lad -- bright and able.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  He's a good lad.  That's why I ask you, MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it'll spoil the boy, eh?  Was I not assistant to Knox?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Aye --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it spoil me, Meg, my lass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks directly at him without answering.  MacFarlane grows uneasy. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (walking up to her, putting an arm around her shoulders and tilting up her chin with his other hand) It will do the boy no harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her off-handedly.  She wraps her arm around his neck and kisses him with fierce passion.  He releases himself, goes on into the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The anatomy room is dim.  Long level bars of light come through the wide windows to illuminate the bare austerity this classroom.  The long rows of tables have a sombre an empty look.  Everything is meticulously clean. At one of the tables is the hunched, dark and evil figure Joseph, the janitor of the school.  He is engaged in rubb the surface of a marble-topped table.  The door on the landing opens.  MacFarlane and Fettes come through.  MacFarlane still has his arm linked through that of his y friend and is listening to Fettes' gratitude with evident pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- all my gratitude, sir -- I can never express it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT -- Fettes and MacFarlane as they descend t stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly) They'll be satisfaction enough for me to know I've trained the great Dr. Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT to include Joseph in the f.g. and Fettes and MacFarlane as they reach the floor level of the anatomy r Joseph, continuing his work, casts a sidelong glance at t doctor and student.  It is evident he is listening to eve word they say. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Now -- as to your duties.  It is up to you to keep the accounts and to distribute the specimens to the students.  Also, inasmuch as you'll be living in the house --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over and glances at Joseph and having noticed th Joseph is eavesdropping, breaks off short. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (to Joseph) Joseph --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph looks up. MACFARLANE (cont'd) What are you doing, sneaking about here like a Redskin?  Make a little noise, man.  Let people know you're about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meekly) Yes, Doctor -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- otherwise I might get the idea you are trying to spy on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Fettes' arm again and leads him off toward the o end of the anatomy room.  The two medicals go out of ears with Joseph in the f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the small out-cropping of the main room set a few feet lower in level.  At one end is a heavy curtain of gr baize. MED. FULL SHOT.  MacFarlane and Fettes descend the steps leading to the alcove.  MacFarlane, with his hand on the elbow of the younger man, guides him to the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how we get the specimens we use for dissection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the Municipal Council -- they're the bodies of paupers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA BEGINS TO DOLLY SLOWLY TOWARD them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what the law stipulates but there are not enough of them, Fettes -- there are not enough of them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane pulls aside the curtain.  He and Fettes pass through and the curtain falls into place behind them.  Th CAMERA CONTINUES TO TRUCK SLOWLY TOWARD the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT.  The little dog, Robbie, is lying on his mast grave.  He lies with his muzzle on his forepaws but his e are open and alert.  Out of the scene comes the plodding of a horse's hoofs and the rumbling of iron-shod wheels. dog lifts his head. The horse comes to a stop.  There is the creak of springs someone alights.  The dog's hackles rise.  He growls. ANOTHER ANGLE.  The great black shadow of a man in a cape overcoat and top hat with a spade over his shoulder is th onto the wall of Greyfriar's Kirk by the street lamp.  Th huge shadow looms high over the tiny dog.  Robbie rises valiantly to his feet, snarling.  As he does so, the actu figure of the man, as black and indistinct as his own sha comes past the camera, blacking out the little dog.  Ther a deeper growl from Robbie.  The man swings his spade dow As the spade drives home there is a little weak sound fro the dog. ANOTHER ANGLE.  With his foot, Gray pushes the dead body the little dog to one side, strikes the spade into the gr and starts to dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a little attic room, Fettes is sleeping fitfully.  The room is flooded with moonlight which comes in through a skylight window. MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes sleeping.  Far away can be hear the plodding hoofbeats and creaking wheels of Gray's cab. There is a loud squeak as the cab takes the turn into the alleyway.  Fettes wakens.  He listens.  There is a sound the hoofbeats, the wheels and then silence when the horse comes to a stop.  He sits up.  From downstairs comes a stealthy knocking at the door.  He gets up sleepily and starts to put on his worn bathrobe, crosses to the window looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE SHOT from Fettes' window.  Gray, his cab and t white horse present a weird and funereal spectacle.  Gray fumbling with something inside the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes has turned from the window and starts toward the d He opens it and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray is pulling a long, canvas-colored object of consider weight from the cab.  With a grunt he gets it up into his arms and starts across the sidewalk toward the postern do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dark except for a small oil lamp left burning as a nightlight.  This casts its dim rays over a small portion the room near the entrance door.  Fettes comes through th door on the landing.  He peers over the bannisters and th somewhat slowly, as if not too easy at the prospect befor him, he begins to descend the stairs. ANOTHER ANGLE.  Fettes crosses the anatomy room looking apprehensively into the darkness at either end.  At the d he pauses a moment, then passes through into the darkness the entry and is lost to view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so dark that Fettes can barely be seen.  The clank the chain as he throws it off and the snap of the bolt ar loud and frightening in this small enclosed space.  He pu the door open.  Before him silhouetted against the dim radiance of the cab lamps is Gray.  In his arms is a long cloth-covered object. CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes as he opens the door wider to give G entrance.  Without a word, Gray carries the body past him into the anatomy room.  Fettes closes the door and follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray comes in and stands waiting for Fettes to come up to him.  Fettes comes out of the entry and takes a few steps toward Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- give me a hand -- this is heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes helps him.  Gingerly he takes hold of the corpse a together they lay it down on a long marble-topped table i the center of the room, almost directly under the nightli Gray heaves a sigh of relief to be relieved of the weight GRAY (cont'd) You'll find the specimen in good condition.  He was bright and cheerful as a thrush not a week long gone.  A likely lad, I'm told. (glances at Fettes) You're the new assistant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to remember his manners) I'm Donald Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very pleased to know you, Master Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Gray, the cabman.  I've had a bit of dealing with MacFarlane in the past, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods. GRAY (cont'd) And I've always gotten along with his assistants -- providing they understood my humble position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts one hand on Fettes' arm.  Fettes moves away from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. MacFarlane said I should pay you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Of course -- it's the soul of the business -- the pay --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes shifts uneasily, confused and seemingly uncertain his next step. GRAY (cont'd) (prompting him) I have no doubt you have the key in your pocket --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes reaches into his pocket and brings out a big iron GRAY (cont'd) (pointing) And there is the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start over toward it.  Fettes opens the box. GRAY (cont'd) My fee is as usual -- ten pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes counts out the money to him.  Gray flips the last into the air and catches it with a gamin gesture which is surprising in a man of such sinister appearance.  As Fett still stands rather stupidly, Gray prompts him again. GRAY (cont'd) And now, although it's none of my business, I would make the proper entry if I were you.  "One specimen -- ten pounds -- received from -- let us say -- "MacDuff" -- a royal name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes looks toward the desk. GRAY (cont'd) (still prompting him) It's the little cloth-covered book in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes brings it out.  Gray watches him while he writes. pen scratches and squeaks over the paper.  Then both turn start toward the entry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door Gray tips his hat elegantly to Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My respects, Master Fettes, and may this be the first of many profitable meetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves, disappearing in the darkness of the entryway. second later the door can be heard closing behind him.  Fettes stands for a long moment looking at the dark entry then from behind him comes a chuckle of laughter.  He whi abruptly. ANOTHER ANGLE -- Fettes in the b.g. and above him on the landing, holding a candle, is Dr. MacFarlane in an elegan dressing gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, my boy.  Your first meeting with the redoubtable Gray.  You may count it as a milestone in your medical career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes as he looks from MacFarlane to door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My medical career --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- skeleton.  It is facing the camera, its sta a parody of that prize fighter of the period; left well extended, right held high, both knees bent.  Over the sho comes a clamor of men's voices, cutting across which, suddenly, comes Fettes' voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, gentleman -- that will do!  Settle down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the interior of the school. the f.g. is the dais, at one side of which is the skeleto Fettes steps up onto the dais at the other side of the passing some dozen students, all young men in their early twenties.  Two students, Gilchrist and Richardson, are prominent.  Richardson is lean and sardonic. FETTES (cont'd) Dr. MacFarlane has asked me to review the points he has just discussed with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- dais.  The skeleton is to one side in f.g. facing the students, o.s.  Fettes has his back to it FETTES (cont'd) He started with the construction of the ribs and the haemapophyses --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns toward the skeleton, then reacts sharply as he notices its ludicrous stance. FETTES (cont'd) (angrily) I suppose this was your doing, Richardson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts rearranging the skeleton's limbs.  Richardson grins.  It is at this moment that Joseph comes sidling up the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Fettes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes looks over at him. JOSEPH (cont'd) A lady is asking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What lady, Joseph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph shrugs.  Fettes, seeing that he'll get no enlightenment from him, turns to the students. FETTES (cont'd) If you gentleman will excuse me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the stairs.  There is a snicker of laughter Richardson leans over and with two deft movements brings arms of the skeleton back into fighting position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh sits there.  Broad beams of sunlight flood in the front windows.  She is speaking with Meg Cameron.  Me standing looking down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you come here?  The Doctor said he wouldn't operate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already told you I didn't come to see Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then whom do you wish to see in MacFarlane's own house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is at this moment that the door opens and Fettes comes Meg takes one glance at him. MEG (cont'd) (almost under her breath) So it is in that direction that the wind blows, eh?  It will get you nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that she turns on her heel and goes off to a little on the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Good morning, Mr. Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes bows formally.  It is obvious he is pleased, yet v puzzled to see her.  He comes down and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked to see me, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impulsively) I want you to help my little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only a student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina told me how kind you were to her.  It gave me hope you might intercede for us with Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that I can do that, Mrs. Marsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he tell you about Georgina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) Then he must have told you that this disease is progressive -- that it will grow worse -- that soon she will not be able to move at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods again.  Mrs. Marsh lays her hand on his arm a looks directly into his eyes. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) And you won't ask him to help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it that way.  I meant only that I am not in a position to ask favors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask this one favor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very much moved) Of course I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina was right.  You are a kind man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She extends her hand and Fettes takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do what I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks with her to the door, lets her out, closes it be her and then turns and starts back the way he came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane is present and now in contrast to the disorder under Fettes the students are busy and absorbed.  They ar working at their tasks.  MacFarlane, with two or three ar him, is helping one of the students, Gilchrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) In an adult this muscle can apply more than one hundred seventy-five pounds of pressure?  Double that and you get the full strength of the human jaw. (jocularly) That, gentlemen, is to chew our food and bite our enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students laugh; that peculiar laugh common to student and soldiers when a superior makes a joke.  It is at this moment that Fettes starts down the stairs.  MacFarlane lo up. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Here, Fettes, life can't be all skittles and ladies --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sally provokes a low murmur of appreciative laughter from the students.  Fettes, discomfited, joins the group. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (pulling a watch from his pocket) It's time for our luncheon.  I've a bit of beef to discuss and -- (bowing slightly) I leave you all to whatever arrangements you have made to serve the inner man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT -- Fettes as he takes up a small bundle wrapped a handkerchief and starts for the door. MED. SHOT -- MacFarlane as he starts for the stairs.  He passes a table where Richardson is bent over his work, wh is out of scene. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Well, I see you have that arm you've been yearning for, Richardson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  This fellow must have been a great one at hurling the bar -- beautiful biceps.  Burke and Hare would never have got the best of this fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane's head jerks up and he looks directly at Richardson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was making a joke, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing on) It's a poor subject for jest, Richardson -- particularly for a medical student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns abruptly away and starts toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Richardson) What did you say to His Imperial Highness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but a merry word about Burke and Hare --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nothing for him to get upset about.  They're dead and buried --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richardson shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes comes along the street toward the gateway.  Sudden he stops and looks at a small crowd which has gathered ar the gate, all talking very excitedly and peering in over other's shoulders.  He stands and looks. MED. FULL SHOT -- the crowd at the gate.  The people draw back making way for Mrs. MacBride who comes out. MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Mrs. MacBride as she makes her way thr the crowd.  She is crying and in her arms she carries the dead body of the little dog. ANOTHER ANGLE -- SHOOTING FROM behind Fettes.  Mrs. MacBr comes through the crowd and starts across the street towa him. CLOSE SHOT -- Mrs. MacBride and Fettes.  Fettes looks at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she passes him) They killed his wee doggie too -- little Robbie. (passes on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- Fettes as he watches Mrs. MacBride.  From behind him comes the sound of the street singer's song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane is seated on a high stool at a work table.  He before him two large bones and is measuring these with a of dividers and marking down notations in a notebook.  Wh he works he whistles "The Blue Bells of Scotland."  There a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over his shoulder to see Fettes as he enters the turns back to his work.  Fettes comes up and stands besid him.  MacFarlane makes a notation in the notebook and the looks up. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Well, Fettes -- where have you been?  I didn't see you at the afternoon session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can go on, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whirling around on the stool) What the devil do you mean?  You have your lodgings, a certain stipend -- I thought I had arranged everything for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the woman whose son's body was delivered last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane nods. FETTES (cont'd) That man took the body from Greyfriar's.  I knew the woman.  I knew the little dog on the grave.  He killed the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's why you don't want to be a doctor, Fettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I have to be party to things like that, Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane studies him for a moment.  He then gets up fro the stool and puts his hand on the boy's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes, I was an assistant once.  I had to deal with men like Gray.  Do you think I did it because I wanted to?  Do you think I want to do it now?  But I must and you must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes shakes his head.  MacFarlane puts his other hand o Fettes' other shoulder. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Ignorant men have dammed up the stream of medical progress with stupid and unjust laws.  If that dam will not break, the other men of medicine have to find other courses.  You understand me, Fettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this woman -- and her son --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for the woman, Fettes.  But her son might be alive today had more doctors been given the opportunity to work on more human specimens.  As for me, Fettes, I let no man stop me when I know I'm right -- when I know that I need those lifeless subjects for my student's enlightenment and for my own knowledge.  And if you're a real man and want to be a good doctor, you'll see it as I see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause.  MacFarlane lets his hands drop to sides. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Well, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods.  MacFarlane claps him jovially on the back. MACFARLANE (cont'd) You're a good lad, Fettes. (looking at Fettes more closely) But you look a bit pale to me.  I'm dining at Hobbs.  Come along with me and have a bit of the joint and a glass of ale.  It will put new life in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the boy's arm and they start from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pavement is glistening from a recent rain and there i hint of fog in the air.  It is the dinner hour and the st is fairly well peopled.  On one corner by the light of a flaring torch a pamphleteer is selling his wares.  On the other corner the street singer stands chanting her ballad the dolorous phrases reciting the tale of a dead knight deserted by his horse, his hound and his leman fair. MED. FULL SHOT -- the singer.  MacFarlane, with top hat, and carrying a cane swings briskly past her with Fettes, soberly dressed, at his side.  They stride out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane with Fettes in tow comes breezing up.  With a lordly gesture he ushers Fettes before him into the publi house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is bright, warm and cheerful.  A huge fire is roaring the fireplace and before it is a rack spit turned by a sp boy who sings as he turns.  (Song to be supplied.)  On th spit is a young porker with forelegs and hind legs stretc to elongate him before the fire.  The porker has just recently been put on the spit so that he gleams pale whit the warm glow of the fire. MED. FULL SHOT -- at the door.  Fettes, followed by MacFarlane comes in.  Fettes looks shyly around him while man servant takes his hat.  MacFarlane boldly flings his and cape to the attendant and strides forward toward the fireplace.  He extends his hands and looks at the slowly turning porker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fettes) We'll have a stiffener or two of hot rum and by then we will be able to meet this fellow on fairly equal terms of warmth, eh Fettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind them comes an insinuating voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine "specimen" isn't he, Toddy MacFarlane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both twist around quickly. REVERSE SHOT -- on the opposite side of the room where he hidden from them by the high walls of the divan, a sort o inglenook built away from the fireplace, is Gray.  This i "common" section of the inn.  He sits with a loaf of coar bread before him and a glass of stout at his elbow.  He i grinning.  Without rising, Gray beckons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Toddy -- come.  Sit down here with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me that confounded name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still grinning) Well, then, Doctor MacFarlane -- although I've known a time, Toddy, when you liked the name.  Aye, and many are dead now who called you by it; rough and wild ones they were, too.  But come Toddy, sit down here with your young friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes looks in surprise from the doctor to the cabman, utterly confused at the familiarity of this man's address

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Mr. Fettes and I have professional matters to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medicine?  That'll keep.  Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As MacFarlane hesitates, angry and most anxious to refuse Gray lowers his tone to a sly confidential murmur. GRAY (cont'd) You wouldn't want it said of you that you refused a glass to an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll buy you a glass, Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions to Fettes to sit down.  Fettes takes a seat an MacFarlane sits down beside him.  As Fettes sits down bes him, Gray turns to him in a confidential manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a pretty bad fellow myself, but MacFarlane is the boy -- Toddy MacFarlane --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chuckles, shaking his head as if in appreciation of th most sinister sort of villainy.  MacFarlane is angry.  Fe is confused and unable to orient himself in this strange relationship between the great anatomist and the lowly cabman.  Gray turns to MacFarlane. GRAY (cont'd) Come, Toddy, order for your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane lifts his hand to beckon to the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, on second thought, let me order. (as the waiter comes up) We'll have a bowl of hot punch and a cut off the loin from that fine porker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter looks at Gray dubiously, unused to such a sumptuous order from so humble a customer. GRAY (cont'd) (catching the look) You needn't worry, waiter, I'm with my friend -- the great Dr. MacFarlane -- he wants to sit here with the commonality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter nods, looks from MacFarlane's tense and angry to Gray's grinning countenance, turns and makes off to th kitchen.  For a moment the three men sit silently, MacFar encircled in the iron ring of his anger; Fettes tongue-tied and abashed and Gray gloating over the doctor's discomfiture.  Finally Gray breaks the silence. GRAY (cont'd) (to MacFarlane) Well, you were going to talk of medical matters.  Don't let my humble presence stop you.  Speak up, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane, goaded beyond the point of endurance, pounds fist on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not have you use that name to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men glare at each other, then very slowly MacFarl averts his gaze.  Fettes looks from one to the other and trying to cover the defeat of his teacher, begins to spea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. MacFarlane -- you remember the lady who came to see you yesterday -- the lady with the little girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She came again today.  She wanted me to ask you if you would not break your rule and operate.  She feels you are her only hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she told me.  I'm a teacher -- not a practitioner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane shrugs as if this aspect of the conversation w closed.  Gray looks over at him quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a teacher, eh?  Maybe you're afraid to be a doctor, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid you are not as good a doctor perhaps as you make out to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the best man for the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you do it then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses and looks slyly at MacFarlane. GRAY (cont'd) I'd like you to do the operation, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?  Why?  Since when have you become the protector of little children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not concerned about the child, Toddy.  It's you I'm thinking of, I'd like to see you prove that a lot of things I know haven't hurt Toddy MacFarlane any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll not do it, Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, you will.  You'll do it to oblige Fettes and myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there's some private reason between you and me which will make you -- some long lost friend of ours. (dropping his voice) Say that you'll do it for me and my friend, Mr. Fettes, here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men exchange glances for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to cover up) It might be an interesting case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good boy, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOTE:  The following line to be shot as protection for th content of this scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only want me to do it because I don't want to.  That's it, isn't it, Gray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane glares at him with hatred.  Gray grins and tur to Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toddy hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Don't call me that confounded name, I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear him?  Did you ever see the lads play knife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the table knife and puts it across his knuckl then with a sweep of his fist, tosses it into the loaf of bread. GRAY (cont'd) He would like to do that all over my body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to make a joke) We medicals have a better way than that.  When we dislike a friend we dissect him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane looks up sharply.  Gray glances at him and smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never get rid of me that way, Toddy.  You and I have two bodies -- aye, very different sorts of bodies -- but we're closer than if we were in the same skin -- for I saved that skin of yours once and you'll not forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter comes, bearing a steaming bowl of punch.  He ladles out a glassful and puts it before MacFarlane.  MacFarlane drinks thirstily, glad of this excuse to avoid Gray's penetrating glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ramparts of the castle of Edinburgh are about thirty wide and overgrown with the grass of centuries.  This for narrow lawn between two crenellated stone walls.  From th battlements only a distant horizon line, a few spires and fleecy clouds above the town can be seen. LONG SHOT -- a small group of children.  The CAMERA PANS these children as they run, laughing and shouting, across lawn of the ramparts.  When they run past the little wheelchair in which Georgina is seated, the CAMERA HOLDS Georgina.  She turns her head to watch the children run o Then she turns and looks the other way to where her mothe and Fettes are standing by the ramparts, deep in conversation.  The CAMERA PANS WITH her gaze.  They are o of earshot of the child talking in low, confidential tone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have his promise, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh looks over at Georgina, then back to Fettes.  Fettes turns and looks over at Georgina. FETTES (cont'd) There will be great pain connected with it, ma'am.  During the operation and afterward -- great pain and shock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost breathing the words) -- pain -- and shock.  She's brave enough, but I don't know about myself.  Now that it seems so close, I wonder if I dare trust my child into any but God's hands.  Maybe He knows best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, is you'll allow me, I'd like to give you cause for courage -- Dr. MacFarlane is a great man -- I think he's the greatest man in medicine.  God would not have given him such gifts if they were not meant for Georgina's cure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh looks at him gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Thank you, Mr. Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Georgina.  Seated in her little wheel chair, she is cuddling a porcelain-faced doll of the peri Suddenly she hears something in the street far below.  It the clop-clop of horse's hoofs and the ringing of wheels the cobble stones.  She looks up and tries to raise herse in her wheel chair to see over the parapet.  She is unabl do so.  She calls out to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommie!  Mommie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT -- Georgina in the f.g.  Fettes and Mrs. M turn to go toward her. GEORGINA (cont'd) Push me to the wall, Mommie.  I think I hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes takes a few long steps and comes up to the wheel chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white horse.  The horse that is going to greet me when he sees me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he starts to wheel the chair toward the parapet) An old acquaintance, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina nods.  He gets her as far as the wall and she lo over.  She peers down, then turns back with a look of disappointment on her face. DOWN SHOT -- from the Ramparts.  On the street below a carriage is passing drawn by a brown horse. MED. CLOSE SHOT -- Georgina and Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) It was a brown horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cabby told her his horse would say "hello" to her the next time he saw her.  Georgina has been looking everywhere for that horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes looks at the child, smiling, then leans down so as bring himself on a level with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you want the white horse to bid you "good-day"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a nice horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there's another reason.  Maybe you haven't friends enough.  Could that be it, Georgina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina looks at him, thinks a moment, then nods her hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course -- I don't have friends.  That's because I can't walk.  I try to make myself used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One shouldn't get used to the wrong things, Georgina.  You want to walk and run and play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not knowing the direction or purpose of Fettes' conversation; breaks in) Really, Mr. Fettes -- I thought you at least would know how much Georgina wants that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, but I still wonder how much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with dreadful sincerity) I want it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll have to stand great pain, Georgina.  Greater pain than you ever dreamed of in the worst time of your sickness.  Do you want it that much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina nods. FETTES (cont'd) Then, Dr. MacFarlane will make you well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at her and although this direct conversation ab her illness has brought tears to her eyes, Georgina smile back at him and Mrs. Marsh, looking down at them, smiles In her eyes also are tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane is seated in a wing chair before the fire.  Although it is near noon, he still wears dressing gown an slippers.  His hair is rumpled and his eyes bloodshot.  H has a glass in his left hand and holds a poker in his rig With the poker he tries to push a big piece of cannel coa into the flames.  It eludes the point of the poker and ro back against the hobb.  Again he pushes it forward.  Agai rolls back.  Suddenly, and with almost maniacal rage, he lifts up the poker and brings it crashing down on the coa The soft coal splinters into a hundred pieces.  Suddenly, from behind him comes a woman's soft and teasing laughter He turns.  Meg Cameron stands in the doorway behind him. comes quickly across the room to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she walks) Gray's head -- is that it, Teddy?  Is that what broke just now under the poker.  Broken it -- and have done with him forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time and she has finished her speech, Meg has reac him and before he has had a chance to even react to her teasing, mocking tones, she has flung herself down on her knees beside his chair, thrown her arms about his neck an kissed him passionately. MEG (cont'd) My poor lad -- my poor, poor lad that can never be free of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're daft.  What's Gray to me.  He's only a man from whom I buy what I need when I need it -- the rest is forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may deny the devil, Toddy, but you'll not rid yourself of him by saying the devil is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense.  You're a fey creature with mad ideas.  But you have a wildness that holds me to you, lass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quite sure of her ground) No great lady will ever take my place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane shakes his head.  He kisses her.  She clings t him.  It is at this moment that there is a knocking at th door.  Meg rises quickly and adjusts her clothing.  MacFarlane tries to seem more at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes comes in. MACFARLANE (cont'd) I didn't expect to see you on Sunday, Fettes.  What do you want, some powders for your aching head?  That was a furious lot we drank last night -- and in bad company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was about last night I wanted to talk to you -- about the operation on the little Marsh girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loftily) You're a man of the world, Fettes, you wouldn't hold me to promise given in drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I -- well, you see, sir, I met Mrs. Marsh and told her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to lose patience) Really, Fettes, you irk me with your lack of understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you did promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here, Fettes.  Not I nor anyone else knows enough about the spinal column and its intricacies to insure success in such an operation.  I would have to study the matter.  Have we any "subjects"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilmont used up the last spinal section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, it is completely out of the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very disappointed) Yes, I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you run off and see that pretty Mrs. Marsh and explain to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes, dejected and disappointed, nods and slowly leaves room.  MacFarlane watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- Joseph at the desk.  He has the account boo open before him and with index finger moving from letter letter, he is laboriously but silently spelling out the words.  Suddenly, he hears footsteps behind him on the st and quickly slams the book and begins dusting the desk. FULL SHOT -- The anatomy room from Joseph's ANGLE.  Fette coming down the stairs and crosses toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph looks up. FETTES (cont'd) Would you know a spinal column if you saw one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph nods and grins. FETTES (cont'd) Do we have one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph shakes his head.  Fettes shrugs.  He stands thinki for a moment, then speaks to Joseph again. FETTES (cont'd) Joseph --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph looks up again. FETTES (cont'd) -- do you happen to know where Gray, the cabman, lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph nods. FETTES (cont'd) Well, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph leans meditatively on the desk. FETTES (cont'd) What do you want me to do, bribe you?  I'm cursed if I do.  Tell me straight out.  Where does he live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd gladly run with a message, sir, for a florin.  It's not much, considering it's Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only want his address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lives in the Westport --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods. JOSEPH (cont'd) (in a last desperate effort) I'd gladly go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Fettes has already passed into the entry way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a crooked, narrow alley.  The only light comes from ends.  Fettes can begin to hear the ballad of the street singer from the street toward which he is going.  He paus moment, listens, then walks forward into the darkness; th song almost seeming to guide him through the dark alley. He comes to the darkest portion of the alley.  A sound fr the left attracts his attention.  He comes to an abrupt h as something white and mysterious moves on a window sill his eye level.  He takes a half step backward as a white leaps down and scurries noiselessly across his path.  Fet grins at his own fright and goes on.  He passes through t darkness and comes out into the dim light of the other street.  He comes to the street corner and on the corner stands the street singer.  She is singing her little song jingling a few coins in her begging bowl to attract the attention of the few people passing by in this dismal str Fettes goes up to her.  She stops singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where Mr. Gray lives -- Gray, the cabman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl shakes her head. FETTES (cont'd) Well, thanks anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a coin from his pocket and drops it into her bow He goes off and the CAMERA MOVES IN to a BIG CLOSEUP of t girl as she resumes her song. LONG SHOT -- Fettes as he walks.  This alley, like the ot grows darker toward the center.  There is an arch leading a court.  Fettes turns left under this arch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a tiny, narrow squalid building.  He looks at it, s the name, "John Gray -- Cabman" written on a board across door, goes up to it and knocks.  As there is no answer, h pushes the door open and steps into almost Stygian darkne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes gropes his way along the wall toward the stairs.  Suddenly from the darkness looms a tremendous white figur It is the cabman's horse.  His first momentary fright ove Fettes pats the horse's nose, passes on to the stairs, cl the brief flight of steps leading to a door from under wh comes a ray of light.  Again he knocks.  A voice shouts o to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in -- come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes thrusts open the door and looks around to see the in which he finds himself.  It is a large loft-like room, furnished with odds and ends of poor furniture.  The best pieces in the room are two dilapidated easy chairs that h obviously seen better days.  On one wall some spare harne is hung.  A great battered wardrobe contains Gray's cloth The floor is covered with two worn Turkey carpets.  There a bed on which the bedclothes are untidily tumbled.  Ther a washstand and pitcher.  Quite evidently Gray uses this chamber as a combined living, dining and bedroom as well kitchen.  This last is the purpose to which it is being p as Fettes enters.  Gray, in shirt sleeves, is crouched ov the embers of the fire in the hearth, stirring some sausa in a frying pan.  The kettle steams busily on the hob.  O small table near the fire is a loaf of bread, a jug of al wooden trencher, a clasp knife and a fork.  As Fettes ent Gray rises and goes to meet him with the frying pan still his left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's the young doctor come to see me.  I'm honored -- honored --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a curious, almost triumphant undertone in his vo GRAY (cont'd) Here, take this.  It is the most comfortable chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He guides Fettes to a chair and Fettes, without removing coat, sits down. With quick servile civility he crosses to the taboret, ge glass and bottle and brings it back with him.  He pours a glass for Fettes. Fettes takes a swallow. GRAY (cont'd) And to what do I owe this honor of this visit?  Some business, was it, of Dr. MacFarlane's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. MacFarlane didn't send me.  I came of my own accord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off, taking another swig from his glass. FETTES (cont'd) What are the chances of your being able to get us a "subject"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) It would be difficult -- very difficult.  There was a dog that bothered me during the last job -- people seem so concerned about dogs -- all in all it raised the very mother and father of a row.  I'm told the kirkyards are to be guarded. (pausing) But I would not like to say that it would be impossible to get a "subject".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of relief comes over Fettes' face.  He picks up hi glass and drinks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) But how soon, man?  Dr. MacFarlane is engaged in some very urgent research at present.  He can't wait very long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again Gray smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fear he may have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But can't you give me any idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I?  I will do my best.  After all, you see, I am financially interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK to a WIDER ANGLE as Fettes gets to feet abruptly.  Where comes very faintly over the shot fr somewhere outside, the voice of the street singer, singin the same melody. GRAY (cont'd) You may tell Toddy that I will do what I can, when I can -- as he knows I will. (sighing) But he must wait and see as the children do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's your answer -- it'll have to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes turns abruptly away and goes quickly out of scene toward the door.  Gray sits for a moment, reflecting, the gets to his feet.  The CAMERA PANS WITH him as he goes to door and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT -- at the far side of the street, Fettes c be seen striding.  At the nearer side, approaching slowly the street singer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- Gray.  His head is turned in the direction the voice.  His hand comes up to his chin as he rubs at i reflectively, obviously seized by an idea.  He makes up h mind and turns into the stable. MED. SHOT.  It is dark.  In the f.g. is the white horse. turns as Gray comes into scene and nuzzles him affectiona as he pats it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Friend!  There's bad news for you, boy -- bad news --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out a lump of sugar and gives it to the horse. GRAY (cont'd) We have to go out again, Friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away into the darkness, but is back in a moment bearing the horse's collar.  As he slips the collar over animal's head --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a long deserted street.  At the near end a lantern house wall casts a sphere of dim radiance.  The CAMERA is FOCUSED DOWN the street which ends in Stygian darkness. behind the camera comes the street singer, walking slowly singing and rattling her begging bowl.  She walks on.  Ju before her figure is lost in the darkness, from behind th camera can be heard the clop-clop of hoofs, the creak of carriage springs, and the rolling wheels of Gray's cab. the singer disappears completely into the darkness, the c goes past the camera.  It, too, disappears into the darkn The CAMERA HOLDS.  The sound of the carriage ceases.  A moment later, the song of the street singer comes to an abrupt, choked end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a small table, seated on a high stool, is Fettes.  A little lamp burns dimly at his elbow and by its light he studying.  He turns the pages, checks some point in his reading with an anatomical chart spread over the table an with his pencil still poised over the anatomical chart, h pauses, listening.  From some distance away comes the sou of a horse's hoofs and the banging of wheels.  Fettes ris and crosses to the window.  He draws the curtains aside a pushes open the casement.  With the window open and sound the horse's hoofs is louder.  He looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING DOWNWARD as if from Fettes' viewpoint.  Gray's c pulled by the white horse comes into the scene and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes turns away from the window and starts for the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray gets off the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes passing through.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE ENTRY WAY
dialogues.text: Fettes opens the door, admitting Gray.  He comes in carry the usual canvas-colored body, but this burden is lighter than the last.  Without any difficulty he takes it into t adjoining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray lays his burden down upon the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) There, Master Fettes.  Sooner than we had expected.  A stoke of luck one might say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is still almost half asleep as he starts over toward t desk pulling the key from his pocket as he goes.  As he d so, his eyes light on the face of the corpse, revealed on side by the drooping canvas.  He is startled; takes two s nearer and looks again. FETTES (cont'd) That's the street singer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray says nothing; merely looks at him calmly. FETTES (cont'd) (very much excited) I know her, I tell you!  She was alive and hearty only this evening.  It's impossible she can be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses.  Then in a lower voice. FETTES (cont'd) You could not have gotten this body fairly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray looks at him with a cold, hard look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are entirely mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men stand facing each other.  There is even a hin physical violence in Gray's stooped crouch. GRAY (cont'd) You had better give me my money and make the proper entry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares Fettes down and the boy crosses over to the des and hurriedly gets out the money.  He crosses over and gi it to Gray.  Gray looks at it and then at the boy. GRAY (cont'd) Good night, Dr. Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tips his hat and is quickly gone.  Fettes goes back to body and looks down at the dead face of the girl.  He shudders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE FULL SHOT -- the stairway.  The door at the top of stairs opens and MacFarlane comes through with an early morning shine upon his countenance; his hair sleek from brushing.  He is adjusting his tie and is whistling a Scottish tune as he descends the stairs.  He suddenly bre off as he sees someone below him on the floor level of th anatomy room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartily) Well, well, good morning to you, young Master Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE SHOT.  Fettes is completely dressed, but his hagg face and rumpled hair give evidence of a sleepless night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. MacFarlane, have you ever seen a street singer who sang "The Twa Corby"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start toward the table where the body lies.  The CAM BEGINS TO TRUCK WITH them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every street singer with a cracked voice gives tongue to that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This girl was beautiful -- a wild lassie from the Highlands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful, you say? It's a wonder I have not remarked her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the table and both me look down. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Oh, this girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whistles a bar or two of her song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph, comfortably seated on a three-legged stool near t brine vat and contentedly sucking at an old clay pipe, he the doctor's whistled tune.  He leans forward without ris parts the curtain to look out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph softly rises from his stool, taking care to let th legs of this seat go back quietly onto the floor.  He put himself into an attitude of intense listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT on MacFarlane and Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to see Gray last night.  I asked him to bring us a specimen.  On my way I saw this girl.  I gave her alms money.  She was alive and singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to her temple.  MacFarlane looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't be sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sure.  I mean to report it.  It's like Burke and Hare all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane studies him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) I wouldn't do that, Fettes.  I wouldn't report it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grave robbing is one thing -- this is murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
