dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- Joseph at the curtain.  He is turning away. has heard enough, and the calculating look in his eyes ha been replaced by one of triumphant decision. MED. SHOT -- Fettes and MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that -- neither do you.  This subject may have been an epileptic -- thrown a fit -- fallen out of bed -- cracked her skull and killed herself -- there is everything explained -- the bruise on her head --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe it or not.  It's best for you to pretend that you do.  After all, it was you who ordered this specimen, received it here, and paid for it.  That makes you a party to murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes looks at MacFarlane.  The truth of what the doctor said is borne in upon him.  He is confused and bewildered

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I didn't ask him to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would believe that?  And you know, someone else might recognize her.  She was as well known as the Castle Rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane looks over at him. MACFARLANE (cont'd) I should advise complete dissection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane starts to pull back the canvas from the body. MACFARLANE (cont'd) I'll help you, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes hesitates.  MacFarlane throws back the canvas shee MED. CLOSE TWO SHOT -- Fettes and MacFarlane. MACFARLANE (cont'd) I want the whole centrum myself for spinal work -- you know why --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes understands, smiles and moves forward to help the doctor lift the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a bright afternoon and there is no fire on the hear Mrs. Marsh is seated on the sofa and Meg sits beside her. tea service on a small table is between them.  Georgina's empty wheel-chair is in evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing a cup of tea toward Mrs. Marsh) Have a drop -- it'll help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh shakes her head.  Between her hands is a handkerchief which she is twisting nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't swallow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a nervous desperate gesture with her handkerchi glances wildly at the clock. MRS. MARSH (cont'd) How long has it been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg Cameron also glances at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately echoing) Only twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT.  The room no longer has its ordinary arrangeme The tables and benches have been pulled up around the cen marble-topped table for use as an impromptu grandstands.  Students are standing on the tables and benches, peering in tense and silent excitement at something on the table. There is the sound of a child's groan; a gasp of pain. CLOSE FULL SHOT -- the circle around the table.  Georgina partially covered by a sheet, lies on the slab.  MacFarla in shirt sleeves and apron bends over her. Richardson and some other students are close around him.  Fettes crouche the head of the table; his face near that of the child. is a very low camera setup which hides the actual busines the operation from the audience, but which allows them to the reactions to it on the faces of the students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is where you must watch closely, gentleman -- closely -- it is the very heart of the matter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, Doctor -- wait!  The child's fainting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two big students who are holding the tiny thin arms o the girl to hold her down look questioningly at MacFarlan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her some brandy if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow -- but not too alarming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends to his work again. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (commenting as he goes) -- and the final step -- we push the ganglia to one side -- then we make the actual osseous incision here -- so -- it is done -- the repair is effected and nothing left to do but replace the tissue and let nature heal what is no longer a defect -- merely a wound --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly; but with feeling) Bravo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fettes) I'll be finished with her in an instant.  Then you can consider her your patient, Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes looks his gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late afternoon and only MacFarlane is there working his desk.  Suddenly Joseph comes in from the entry on tip He gets up to within a few feet of MacFarlane before announcing himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane wheels around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the devil is the matter with you -- forever creeping about.  What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gray --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wish to see Mr. Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind him Gray, grinning, comes out from the darkness of entry way and stands listening.  The doctor is unaware of presence.  He turns back to his work. MACFARLANE (cont'd) You tell him that there will be no more business between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray grins even more broadly, then he clears his throat w a rumbling couch.  MacFarlane turns around. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Oh -- well, Joseph, it seems I will have the pleasure of speaking to Mr. Gray myself.  You can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men wait for Joseph to go into the alcove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that wasn't a friendly thing I heard, Toddy.  Not at all friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That has nothing to do with it.  We've decided to do more lecturing and less dissection -- it's better for the students -- that's all there is to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to leave) You know what you want and don't want -- so that's an end of business between us -- but we'll still be friends, Toddy.  I'll be dropping by to see you and Meg once in a while -- for auld lang syne, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose we can't prevent that, Gray -- (bitterly) -- for auld lang syne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray turns very humbly and goes to the door, then he turn again and he is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you think you're getting rid of me, Toddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane, who has turned back to his desk, whirls about but Gray has already disappeared into the darkness of the entry way and from thence comes his loud crowing laughter The doctor's face clouds in anger.  He turns back to his desk.  The street door can be heard closing.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Gray, still laughing, comes out on the sidewalk to find Joseph waiting for him.  Chuckling to himself,  Gray star to cross to his cab.  Joseph stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to speak to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I presume you shall.  This won't be my last visit here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to speak to you alone.  I saw something.  I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks off and sees Fettes coming down the alley.  Fett is whistling to himself. JOSEPH (cont'd) Maybe some other time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to laugh again) Oh, you'll have ample opportunity -- ample -- (to Fettes) Good morning, Dr. Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor turns as Fettes comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw Gray.  What was he laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has his own idea of a joke.  Perhaps his horse tickled him in the ribs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been to see Mrs. Marsh.  Georgina is doing splendidly.  The incision has healed -- clean and fine -- but she doesn't seem to have any desire to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she's ready you bring her to me -- I'll show her how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. MacFarlane, I wonder if you know what happiness you've brought those people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's only our duty, Fettes -- that's the end at which we aim with all this nasty business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a gesture to include the anatomy room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very sincerely) I suppose one must pass through this purgatory to the heaven of being a good doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to his desk) That's the way of it, Fettes.  You bring the lassie to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor, Fettes, Mrs. Marsh and Georgina are all toget Georgina is seated in her little wheelchair.  The doctor stands before her, looming above her, glowering with ill concealed rage.  Fettes kneels at the side of the wheelch while Mrs. Marsh sits nervously perched on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to find the white horse, Georgina?  You can't find him from a wheelchair.  You have to walk and run to find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thundering) You can't -- can't! (to Fettes) Stop trying to bribe her with childishness about white horses.  Let the child stand and walk -- her spine's all right.  I know it's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she must want to stand.  She must want to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still in a towering rage) Confound me, the child's a cripple, of course she wants to walk. (to Georgina) Child, I say to you get up out of that chair and walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina bursts into tears.  MacFarlane makes a disgusted gesture. MACFARLANE (cont'd) (trying to control himself) I ask you, child, to do a simple thing -- raise yourself with your hands to a standing posture -- then step out with your left foot -- try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina shakes her head. MACFARLANE (cont'd) I say, try it!  Lift yourself up now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina lifts herself up by her hands to a semistanding posture. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Good.  Now step out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child stands still. MACFARLANE (cont'd) Step out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't!  I can't!  My legs won't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost screaming) Nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh rises from the sofa and comes to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Doctor.  Georgina's a good child -- a brave child -- you saw how she was during the operation -- but if she can't move, she can't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she must be able to move.  Everything is in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) She would if she could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then all my surgery is no good.  There's something wrong with the child -- something I don't know -- something I can't define -- can't diagnose. (pause) I can do nothing for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he finishes his speech there is a long, dead silence MacFarlane is the first to break it. MACFARLANE (cont'd) You see Mrs. Marsh home, Fettes, I'm going to Hobbs'.  You can join me there if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods.  Picking up his hat MacFarlane starts from t door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quite late and there are only a few patrons in the public house. At the bar, with his hat on his head and hi whip in one hand, Gray sits on a stool drinking some hot liquid from a pewter tankard. The drawing-waiter is leani on the bar talking to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (setting down the mug) Well, I'll be off -- unless you have a fare for me here -- some gentleman a little taken with wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a bit and MacFarlane will be wanting to be freighted home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor MacFarlane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye. In the other room and getting stiffer than the bodies he demonstrates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll look in on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray slouches across the room to the divan. He peers in.  MED. CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane in the divan FROM GRAY'S AN There is a squat bottle before him and two small glasses. is hunched over. His hair is rumpled. He is brooding. Fro the entrance of the divan, Gray speaks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toddy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with drunken friendliness) Oh, it's you, Gray. Well, come in. Sit down. Have a glass with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (removing his hat and sitting down) You're uncommon friendly tonight, Toddy. More like the old days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane drunkenly nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want someone to talk to. That Fettes -- all taken up with the widow. He never came back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something about the human body, Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had some experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you can understand that the backbone is a lot of little blocks and those little blocks are all held together, so that it works like that whip of yours. You know that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never had it all explained that way to me by so learned a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disregarding the sarcasm) I set those blocks together, patched the muscles. I put the nerves where they should be -- I did it and I did it right -- and she won't walk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to understand) Oh, it's the bit of a girl Fettes was talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thumping his hand on the table) The same. Look here, Gray --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fitted them together like this -- (he puts the two glasses together) -- so that it was right. Yet she won't walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray looks at him. He is grinning his malicious grin. Wit sudden sweep of his hand across the table he knocks down glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't build life like you put together blocks, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? I am an anatomist. I know the body. I know how it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're a fool, Toddy -- and no doctor. It's only the dead ones that you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a doctor. I teach medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Knox taught you? Like I taught you? In cellars and graveyards? Did Knox teach you what makes the blood flow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heart pumps it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he tell you how thoughts come and how they go and why things are remembered and forgot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nerve centers -- the brain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what makes a thought start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fuzzily) In the brain, I tell you. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know and you'll never know or understand, Toddy. Not from me or from Knox would you learn those things. Look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a mirror behind MacFarlane's head.  MacFarla looks into it. MIRROR SHOT showing MacFarlane looking at his own face an the evil face of Gray just behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at yourself, Toddy, could you be a doctor -- a healing man -- with the things those eyes have seen? There's a lot of knowledge in those eyes, but there's no understanding. You'd not get that from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane whirls around. ANOTHER ANGLE - MacFarlane facing Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a doctor - a good doctor. I could make her walk, but she won't  - she won't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost kindly, as he pours a drink) Here, have another glass, MacFarlane. I'll take you home and we'll be friends again -- now that you know that you're Knox's man and my friend -- aye, forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane swallows the drink at a single draught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm my own man and I'll have no more to do with you, Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray lifts his eyebrows quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I be afraid of you? What are you holding over me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what, Toddy. It's because I ran down the streets with the mud and the stones around my ears and the mob yelling for my blood. It's because you were afraid to face it -- and you're still afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not afraid. Tell! Shout it from the housetops! (dropping his voice) And remember this -- they hanged Burke -- they mobbed Hare -- but Dr. Knox is living like a gentleman in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane rises drunkenly to his feet, There is a threat physical violence in his manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat placatingly; for the first time not completely master of the situation) Aye, Toddy, there is something in what you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is much in what I say, Gray, and if you have any regard for your neck you'll leave now and stay away from my house, my school, and from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no wish for a rope cravat. I've never liked the smell of hemp, so I'll bid you good night, Doctor MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray picks up his hat and starts off out of scene. MacFar slumps back into his seat. His hand reaches out for the whiskey bottle. He starts to pour another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the light of a single lantern, Gray is unharnessing hi horse. He leads it out from between the shafts and into i stall. There is a furtive sound before him as the door to street slowly moves open. He wheels quickly as a slight, hunched figure sidles through the door. Gray waits until figure walks into the range of the lamp and is revealed a Joseph. Then he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah -- Dr. MacFarlane's man -- A surprise visit, but come in -- come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps aside, and Joseph slowly moves over toward the stairway, looking around him. MED. SHOT as Gray leads Joseph into the living quarters a looks curiously at Joseph, who returns the look with a so of determined belligerence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome to my little nest, Joseph -- is it not? That's right -- you have something to say to  me -- something very private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that is very interesting -- (with a gesture) Take a chair, Joseph,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph seats himself and Gray sits down opposite him.  No sooner has he seated himself than the big white cat, his comes and jumps upon his knee. Gray strokes it fondly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Can anyone hear what we say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the cat) Only Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bending toward him) I know that you kill people to sell bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray sits motionless except that the hand which rests upo the arm of his chair slowly tenses and that other hand wh strokes the cat, stops at the cat's head.  For a long mom he is silent, then he speaks very softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say you've come here on your own account?  No one knows you are here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me money or I'll tell the police you murder the "subjects."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again there is a silence as Gray studies him.  By now, Gr right hand relaxes.  His left hand begins to stroke the c Finally, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you shall have money, Joseph.  Why should you not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still smiling, he very carefully takes the cat from his l sits it on the floor and rises.  Joseph follows him with eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossing to the taboret for a bottle and two glasses) I don't suppose the great Dr. MacFarlane is too free with his pay, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has come back with the bottle and filled a glass with brandy for each. He passes a glass into Joseph's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- have some of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both drink. Immediately, Gray refills Joseph's glass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he pours) You want money and you shall have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a purse from his pocket and begins to count out notes and coins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see -- five and five -- then in gold -- six all together. Shall we say sixteen pounds, Joseph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph, with the glass still at his lips, nods his head. looks about as if seeking a point of vantage; then carefu sets himself in a straight-backed chair, facing and a lit to the side of Joseph's chair. Joseph is in a low-cushion chair. Gray, being above him, almost seems to hover over Gray leans forward to give him the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have made you give me money, but you smile. Aren't you angry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Joseph. I'm not angry -- here -- another glass of brandy --I'll wager it's better than the doctor's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time Gray fills Joseph's glass and drabbles a few dr into his own, but doesn't bother to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink up, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The liquor has begun to affect Joseph. He takes the third glass eagerly and drains it while Gray watches him in silence. As he puts the glass down, Gray begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an idea -- a splendid idea -- such an excellent idea that we must drink on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fills the fourth glass. Joseph takes it but does not drink, as he is interested to hear Gray's proposition,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see -- I admire you, Joseph. Coming here shows courage. I'm looking for such a man -- but -- drink, Joseph, drink..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph drinks. Again Gray keeps silent while he swallows liquor. As Joseph puts down the glass, Gray hitches his c forward an inch or two. Again he refills the glass; puts into Joseph's unsteady hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I should work together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean we would sell the bodies to the doctors together? Dig them up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) No digging Joseph. The churchyards are too well guarded. We will "Burke" them,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Burke them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are lately come to Scotland, Joseph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come from Lisbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But still you may have heard the peddlers of verse cry out their names on the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to sing in a rough croaking voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The ruffian dogs, the Hellish pair.  The villain Burke, the meager Hare --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard that song. But what did they do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen persons they killed and sold the bodies to Dr. Knox at ten pounds for a large and eight pounds for a small. That's good business, Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph nods appreciatively, then looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where did they get those people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Hare's end. Ah, you should have seen him on the streets, when he saw some old beldam deep in drink how he cozened her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mimics, tipping an imaginary hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A good-day to you Madame Tosspot, and would you like a little glass of something before you take your rest? Come with me to my house and I'll make you my guest. You shall have quarts to drink if you like." (appreciatively) Ah, how he cozened them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could do that. But when he had them there, then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to sing again) "Nor did they handle axe or knife To take away their victim's life -- No sooner done than in a chest They crammed their lately welcome guest."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray rubs his hands together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand the song. Tell me plain how they did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I'll show you how it was done, Joseph. -- I'll show you how they "Burked" them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches out for Joseph's face. Joseph interposes his a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, put your hand down. How can I show you, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph lets his hand swing to his lap. Gray clasps Joseph nose between thumb and forefinger, cupping Joseph's chin against the heel of his palm.  CLOSE SHOT - Joseph with Gray's hand holding his nose and mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how they did it, Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly his hand tenses. Joseph's eyes dilate with terro and his head jerks to one side violently as he attempts t tear his face from the grasp of Gray's hand.  MED. CLOSE SHOT - Gray steadily clutching Joseph's face. throws himself upon the other man and the chair slowly go backward. ANOTHER ANGLE. The two men are on the floor. Gr is lying across the body of his victim, his hand still clutching Joseph's nose and mouth. Joseph struggles convulsively, throwing his arms and legs about, trying to at Gray's body which lies athwart him. With his free hand Gray pins down Joseph's right hand. The man is helpless. violence of his movements grows less and less. For a mome he is still; then he struggles again. CLOSE SHOT - Joseph.  He is making a final desperate effo to pull away from Gray's hand, then his face muscles rela His eye's close.  CLOSE FULL SHOT - Gray and Joseph. Gray looks down at his victim. Joseph is at last unconscious. Gray gets to a kneeling posture, but still keeps his hand on Joseph's no and mouth.  ANOTHER ANGLE. The cat walks up and rubs itself against Gray's left arm. He lets go of Joseph's hand and pats the cat, still keeping his grip on Joseph's mouth and nose.  CLOSE SHOT - Gray as he examines Joseph. Evidently, Josep dead enough to suit him and he lets go his grip.  FULL SHOT as Gray gets to his feet. He crosses the room t cupboard, opens it and takes out a square of folded canva He starts back toward Joseph and stops on the way to pick Joseph's glass from the taboret. He drinks the remainder the liquor in it. Gray kneels down beside Joseph and begi to wrap the canvas about the body. Suddenly, a thought strikes him, and he puts his hand in Joseph's coat pocket fishes out the money he had given him. He begins wrapping canvas around the body again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. The School is in darkness -- except for thin moonlight which filters through the shutters, making stra pattern with the shadows. There is no sound until, abrupt a key turns in the lock of the outside door. It opens and through it comes the figure of Gray in his stove-pipe hat caped coat. Over his shoulder he carries a long, limp and apparently heavy bundle wrapped in sacking. Cautiously, without a sound he carries his grim burden toward the curtained recess.  MED. SHOT at recess. Gray comes into shot. He pushes his through the curtain, which falls back into place, hiding from view. Sounds come from behind the curtain; bumping, shuffling sounds. Then Gray's hand appears momentarily as throws out a bundle of sacking.   After a grunt of effort comes a heavy splash as something is dropped into the big o.s.  FULL SHOT - Gray as he comes from the recess and starts across the anatomy room. When he reaches the stairs he pa a moment, and then, instead of going toward the door, tur and starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single lamp is burning. Meg, in negligee and mob cap, s in an arm chair busily knitting. Opposite her, in a low c sits Gray, his whip in his hand and his hat on the back o his head. He is lounging in the chair and he has a glass ale on the floor beside him. He drinks from it and puts i back on the floor. Meg looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've no need to be so anxious, Meg, MacFarlane's been drunk and away before. He'll be home in good time. Meanwhile, you've got me to keep you company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd call that no good fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a time, lassie -- a time when I used to bring the dashing young doctor to your door -- when you didn't feel so uncommon cold to your old friend Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why must you be on him all the time? Why does it please you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my friend. I like to see my friends -- I like to visit them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the sound of the front door opening. Both look u Heavy dragging footsteps sound in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's come home -- you've no excuse now to bear me company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray makes no move to get out of his chair. MacFarlane st in the doorway. He sees Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going here? Have I not told you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you grudge me a glass with my old crony, Meg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crony indeed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray rises leisurely..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought you something tonight, MacFarlane -- an interesting specimen -- in very good condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've ordered nothing from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take no gifts from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a gift you'll not return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, Toddy. That's not hospitable. I want to discuss business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not to set foot in here again, Gray, for business or any other reason. And you're going out now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seizes Gray by the shoulder. Gray merely looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) I wouldn't do it, Toddy. I wouldn't be rough handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane, somewhat taken aback by the calm and effronte of the man, lets go of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were to throw me out, it might become known that when the great Dr. MacFarlane finds his anatomy school without "subjects" -- he provides them himself and from the midst of his own household ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - THREE SHOT - Gray's manner, fully as much as his ambiguous speech, has put an end to all thought of violen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the devil are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray rises slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look downstairs. Toddy. Take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks quietly out of the room.  MacFarlane stares after him; than slowly a thought comes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes -- where is Fettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves quickly. When she has left, MacFarlane passes hand over his eyes, trying to clear his whiskey-muddled brain; then he turns and starts for the door of the anato room,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school is dark and empty; only moonlight enters from windows. The night light is out. MacFarlane comes slowly the stairs. As he reaches the foot of the steps, Fettes, his bathrobe, comes to the head of the stairs, bearing a candle. MacFarlane turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes, were you down here when Gray came?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes shakes his head.  MacFarlane starts for the alcove and Fettes follows him. MacFarlane pulls the curtain asid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring that candle over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT - in the recess. It is very dark. The cur is drawn back, and MacFarlane appears. The scene is sudde illuminated as Fettes follows him, carrying the candle. T great vat is clearly visible as both men peer down into i CLOSE SHOT - the vat, SHOOTING DOWNWARD. Something is floating just beneath the liquid which comes nearly to th top of the vet. Light from the candle o.s, comes over the scene, and the thing below the surface is revealed as the dead face of Joseph. TWO SHOT - MacFarlane, as he takes the candle from Fettes hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) -- a member of his household --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane turns to Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes, the more things are wrong, the more we must act as if everything were right. You must do with Joseph as you did with, the street singer -- complete dissection -- a proper entry in the book --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Fettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have no more to do with it. I'll not put my neck into the noose, not even for your sake, Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool.  One can't begin and then stop -- and because that entry of the girl's body is in your hand, you'll do as I say. As for me, I'll tend to Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane turns and starts for the main portion of the anatomy room.  At the curtain he stops, Meg is standing there, her eyes wide as she looks at the body of Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts past her.  She seizes hold of his arm, crying o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a swoop of his arm he frees himself. Meg almost fall She strikes against the wall, but recovers herself and st after MacFarlane, but it is already too late. He is in th entryway, and a moment later there is the slam of the doo Meg stands trembling. Fettes comes up to her and takes he elbow to support her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Mistress Cameron -- this is no place for you. I'll help you upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets him lead her to the stairway. CLOSE TWO SHOT -- the stairway as Meg and Fettes start to ascend.  Fettes i helping Meg. Suddenly she stops dead and stares into his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must leave this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that -- you heard MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save yourself. Master Fettes look at MacFarlane and be warned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a great doctor -- a great man --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a great man whom Gray can order to his bidding? Is it a great man who for very shame dare not acknowledge his own wife so that I must play maidservant for the world's sake and his success?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a contemptuous gesture and goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could have been a great man -- a good man and a fine doctor, but there was always the shame of the old life and the old ways to hold him back -- and always Gray -- Gray to hound him to his death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're over-excited, Mistress Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cold as ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Gray's only a cab driver -- a Resurrection Man who robs graves to make a bit of money now and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he were only that. The man's evil himself. Some day you'll know him as MacFarlane knows him -- for MacFarlane he was to Knox as you are to him. That brought him close to Gray, he roistered with him and drank with him. Aye, and Gray even brought him to my door and my love. There is all that between them and more -- Burke and Hare and Knox --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's long since.  Gray can't threaten him with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray has no need to threaten. You remember the trial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard my parents speak of it in Thrums. It was a famous case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you hear them speak of the porter who testified against Burke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did not tell you how that porter cried out in the witness box when the Kings Counselor pressed him hard -- how he cried out that he was shielding a gentleman of consequence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That porter was Gray and the gentleman of consequence who couldn't swallow the shame of it -- who took my last paltry savings to hire Gray --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand for a moment looking at each other then she tu wildly toward Fettes and seizes his coat lapels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Fettes, I'm one part befuddled with drink, one part over-heels in love with MacFarlane, and one part fey. You're a lowlander, Fettes, and you have no way of knowing what we Highlanders call the second sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a gift to my people -- and I see MacFarlane and Gray-- the pit yawns for them and the flames -- and I would have you away from them and safe out of the torment.--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two stand facing each other, Meg crushing the boy's c lapels in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very dark as Gray opens the door. For a moment his distinctive silhouette is in the doorway. Then he closes door behind him and the room is again plunged into darkne except for a glow from the embers in the hearth. Gray cro to the hearth. He takes a spill from the mantle, blows on coals and lights the spill. Its flaring light reveals MacFarlane standing watching him. After a first momentary check of surprise, Gray, without a word, transfers the fl from the spill to a candle.  He blows out the spill and s it back on the mantle. MED. SHOT with Gray in the f.g. and MacFarlane coming tow him. Gray has recovered his composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very softly) This is unexpected, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane comes to a halt facing Gray. The CAMERA BEGINS CHEAT IN ON the pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toneless) I wanted to see you. You weren't here -- so I waited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men survey each other in absolute silence. From o near at hand, the cat mews. The CAMERA PULLS BACK TO SLIGHTLY WIDER ANGLE as Gray tur away, seating himself upon the arm of a chair. The cat co into the shot and jumps up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawing closer) What do you want of me. Gray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Want of you, Toddy? I want nothing of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT - Gray and MacFarlane.  MacFarlane is tense, motionless. He stares down at Gray who sits at his ease stroking the cat, now purring on his knee. MacFarlane makes an obvious effort to control himself, to speak calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray, I must rid myself of you -- you've become a cancer -- a malignant, evil cancer -- rotting my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring a drink for MacFarlane) So, Toddy, you've made me a disease, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disregarding this sarcasm, but taking the proffered glass) I can't understand your hurt to me -- but I must cut you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks, sets down the glass. Gray watches him, gets up from his chair and stands before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not leave here until I have finished with you. Gray. One way or another -- I must be sure that I am rid of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses and looks at Gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if there is no other way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray looks at MacFarlane, big and bulky in the small chai He moves nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you are not threatening an old friend, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have never been friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray moves over to the chair on which he sat when he "Bur Joseph. He bends forward over the taboret and refills the doctor's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have another glass of something good, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've drunk enough tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting the glass down on the taboret) Another little drop'll never do you any harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost as if unconscious of his action, MacFarlane picks the glass, sips, then drinks. Gray smiles. MacFarlane set down the glass. Gray immediately refills it. And again MacFarlane reaches for it, takes it into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Drink --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane, without thought, brings the glass to his lips

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting old, Gray, and it's a hard life driving a cab through these wet and windy streets of Edinburgh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have other means of sustenance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Resurrection business? That may end sooner than you think. New laws may come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I was going to say is this -- wouldn't you be more comfortable at Leith in a neat little house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you bribe me to leave you be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would make you rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be half so much fun for me. Toddy, as to have you come here and beg --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) Beg -- beg of you! You crawling graveyard rat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chokes off the last speech and glares at Gray. He is almost trembling with the effort to control himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye -- that is my pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks he is refilling MacFarlane's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then -- I beg you -- I beseech you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking, his head and grinning) But then I wouldn't have the fun of having you come here and beg again, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other. MacFarlane bends over in his cha Gray hitches himself forward a little on the table, ready waiting, then relaxes as MacFarlane begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why, Gray? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it would be a hurt to me to see you no more, Toddy. You're a pleasure to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure to torment me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- a pride to know that I can force you to my will. I'm a small man -- a humble man -- and being poor, I've had to do much that I did not want to do. But so long as the great Dr. MacFarlane jumps at my whistle, that long am I a man -- and if I have not that, I have nothing. Then I am only a cabman and a grave-robber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane looks at him.  As he looks, he realizes he has heard the truth and that Gray will never leave him in pea Now he, in turn, attempts cunning.  He moves forward in h chair as if wishing to put forth a convincing argument.  MacFarlane starts to rise; his mind made up. Gray sees th is no longer any hope of forestalling violence. He throws himself forward and seizes him as he seized Joseph.  MED. FULL SHOT - MacFarlane and Gray. As MacFarlane rises Gray clings to him and gets his other arm about MacFarlan neck. MacFarlane tries to shake him off; tries to twist a from him. The effort makes him lose his footing.  They fa together.  CLOSE SHOT - MacFarlane and Gray on the floor near the hearth.  Gray still clings to him, every muscle tense. MacFarlane, with his hands under Gray's shoulders, heaves trying to push the man off. He heaves once, twice, a thir time and then lets his arms relax from the futile, enormo effort.  TWO HEAD CLOSEUP - Gray and MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let be, Toddy.  Let be. I have no wish to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane's eyes grow huge and fierce with anger. Now he tries to pummel Gray in order to free himself; raining bl on his back, his head and into his side, Gray grunts with each punishing blow, but never for a moment relaxes his g Finally the piston-like blows grow weaker, the flailing a fail and MacFarlane drops his hands to the floor at his s limp and relaxed.  MED. CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane and Gray as MacFarlane, wit great effort, throws his body to the left, toward the fireplace.  The boiling kettle is upset and the steaming water thrown on both of them.  CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane in agony as the water spurts ove him.  CLOSE SHOT -- Gray. His face is twisted in torment and st rises from his scalded flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay, Toddy -- don't force me to kill you -- I have need of you -- the great need of my pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT -- Gray and MacFarlane.  MacFarlane's arms again relax.  Gray smiles through the pain of his scalding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better Toddy. That's more reasonable,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets go his grip on MacFarlane's face.  No sooner has done so than MacFarlane throws him off with a violent movement. Both men scramble to their feet and face each other. THE CAMERA SWINGS AWAY FROM the two men and FOCUSES ON th wall above a lowboy on which the white cat is sitting. Th cat's great, round eyes seem to be surveying the struggle while above its head the shadows of the two men can be se meeting, struggling, breaking off, rushing together again and all the while there can be heard the sound of blows, hoarse breathing, gasps and hard ejaculations of breath. one indistinguishable figure picks up a chair. The chair breaks with a crash over the head of the other figure and that figure falls out of scene. Only one upright shadow remains above the head of the cat. That shadow picks up a cloak and top hat, puts them on and bends to pick up a bo The shadow of one man carrying the body of the other come toward the cat, the shadow growing huge and out-figure on wall. The cat's fur bristles. It arches its back and snar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the night light is burning over the door at the entr way. The school is lit by its swinging light. Out in the street can be heard the familiar clop-clop of Gray's horse and the ringing of the iron wheels on the roadway.  The CAMERA on DOLLY TRACK MOVES SLOWLY TOWARD the entry d The outer door can be heard opening. There is rustle and noise in the dark entryway. By this time the CAMERA is CLOSEUP on the door as MacFarlane with a canvas-wrapped bundle on his shoulder comes through the doorway, and goe a FULL CLOSEUP of his face. He starts forward.  MED. FULL SHOT - MacFarlane as he throws the body down on the table. He stands there for a moment looking down at i then the noise of a door opening on the stair landing cau him to turn and look up. MED. FULL SHOT - the stairway.  Meg is seen at the head o the stairs, looking down.  ANOTHER ANGLE - MacFarlane is seen from Meg's viewpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Fettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT - the stairway as Meg begins to descend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone. I sent him away. I'll not see another boy harried and torn and made miserable like you, Toddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane looks at her as she descends the stairs. There silence as she crosses the room. She comes to stand besid the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the bundle) You've been with Gray again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg turns away as if to start for the stairs.  He stops h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better look at the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd, better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg resolutely walks up to the table, lifts the canvas an looks down at the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm rid of him forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll not come here again -- sneaking and whining and bullying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg is still silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he'll serve a good purpose -- and tomorrow when the last bit of him is dissected, demonstrated and detailed in the students' notebooks, then at last there's an end to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg still looks at him silently and thoughtfully, then wi slight shake of her head she starts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing his hands together) Next day I'll take his horse and cab to sell at the Pennycuick fair. (pauses; then makes an expansive movement with his hands) Then not a trace left -- rid of him forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the foot of the stairs, Meg turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little boy rolling a hoop goes past the camera. Behind come running a little convoy of children, laughing and shouting. When they have passed the camera, Fettes enters scene. He is dejected. His hands are in his pockets and h head is down as he walks toward Georgina and her mother. Georgina is in her wheelchair. Her head is turned as she watches the children run out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mrs. Marsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this was a school day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not at the school anymore. I left last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left Dr. MacFarlane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes nods. Mrs. Marsh looks at him and then takes his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Georgina) Play by yourself a little. I'd like' to speak to Mr. Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLLY SHOT - as Fettes and Mrs. Marsh walk slowly away fr Georgina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is serious, Donald. What has happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not because of Georgina -- because of Dr. MacFarlane's failure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the failure. I feel that MacFarlane has taught me nothing. He taught me the mathematics of anatomy but he couldn't teach me the poetry of medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT -- Georgina. She is playing with her doll. Suddenly, from far below her she hears the clop-clop of a horse's hoofs and the rumble of iron wheels. She looks up listens.  MED. FULL SHOT - Fettes and Mrs. Marsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I don't want to go on. I feel MacFarlane had me on the wrong road --a road that led to knowledge but not to healing. If there had been any healing in the man, Georgina would be walking now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT - Georgina. She is listening intently. The hoof beat are right underneath her at the base of the castle wall. tries to look over the parapet; cannot. She calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommie! Mommie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - Mrs. Marsh and Fettes. They are talking inten together. Mrs. Marsh is holding her parasol in such a way that it is between her and Georgina.  Georgina's call com very faintly over their conversation. Neither of then tur toward the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was the pain of the operation more than anything else -- she's afraid that if she stands the pain will come again. Nothing Dr. MacFarlane could ever do would take that out of her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Georgina. The hoof beats are beginning to recede. There is a slight wind blowing. She turns around look at her mother and calls again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommie!  Mommie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer. She turns her head back toward the battlements; tries to peer over them and fails. Then, pla a hand on each arm of her little chair, she lifts herself a sort of standing-sitting position. She tries to look ov the wall again. Again she fails. She turns to call to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommie -- the white horse -- I'm sure it's the white horse --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT - Fettes and Mrs. Marsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even so, I could never think of going on -- I've got to find some other profession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT - Georgina. She has gotten herself to the same semi erect position she had been before and now in her despera effort to see over the battlement, she suddenly straighte her knees; her hands lift off the arms of the chair. With knowing it, she is standing. She tries again to look over wall and again the height and distance is too much for he Completely unconscious of what she is doing, she takes a forward step and from this vantage point she can look ove the wall. She turns back with disappointment on her face. calls to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommie! It was another horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE FULL SHOT -- Fettes and Mrs. Marsh with the child i the b.g. They see the child standing. Mrs. Marsh makes a wordless exclamation of joy.  She doesn't even dare to mo for fear this might be a vision.  ANOTHER ANGLE -- Fettes, Mrs. Harsh and Georgina. Mrs. Ma and Fettes run in. CLOSE FULL SHOT-- of the three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're standing, Georgina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child looks down, sees that she is standing and almos instantly grabs at the chair for support.  Very gently Fe pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll not need that again, Georgina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited and almost in tears) I wanted to see the white horse --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes and Mrs. Marsh kneel down close to the child. Mrs. Marsh takes her into her arms. Fettes rises to his feet, face is full of enthusiasm and excitement. His voice trem with the keenness of accomplishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wildly excited) I've got to tell Dr. MacFarlane. I've got to tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the ringing of a doorbell. Meg comes down the stairs.  She crosses the hall and opens the door. Fettes stands there. Meg holds the door open for him to enter an closes it behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mistress Cameron -- you'll not believe it, but the child has walked -- stood and walked. I must tell Dr. MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts forward as if to go on into the study. Meg stop him with her hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can I find him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't went to find him. Your news will keep until I tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I must tell him -- he must know of it. Please -- tell me where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no standing between a fool and his folly. If you must babble your news to him he's at the Fisherman's Tryst. It's the inn at Pennycuik. You can use MacFarlane's horse and gig to get there. He'll welcome the ride back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (already starting to turn; still very much excited) At Pennycuik.  I know the inn.  I can be there in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) And back with MacFarlane and all that he stands for the next day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door for Fettes and closes it after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a long, low-raftered room with a fire of logs burni on the hearth. Outside the wind can be heard blowing and shrilling.  A considerable company has gathered for warmt and food.  MED. CLOSE SHOT -- an amiable rustic, a horse dealer, who stands, booted with whip in hand, talking to several fell bumpkins while the maidservant of the inn serves them ale from a large wooden tray. Their wet clothes are steaming the heat of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sound horse and a closed carriage -- and after I'd talked with him a bit I had his price down to four pounds and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And worth every bit or ten pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts a tankard from the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely, Angus, a man who had won so great a victory in a horse deal would buy the poor loser a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it big as he throws a coin onto the tray) Take him a pot of ale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ale for a Gentleman? It's only French brandy he'd be drinking, and that will be two more shillings, Angus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very reluctantly Angus takes out the additional money. Th girl starts out of scene and the CAMERA PANS WITH her to MacFarlane seated at a small table at the other side of t hearth.  He has just finished dinner and is pushing his p away from him.  The maidservant comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man who bought your horse would like you to have a glass of French brandy at his charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's very civil of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the other side of the hearth the louts around the hors dealer strike up a song.  Outside there is the sound of a horse clattering into the courtyard, then the muffled sho as the driver reins the horse in and the hostler goes to head.  Both MacFarlane and the maidservant listen and loo toward the door.  The door swings open and Fettes stands there, his clothes drenched with rain.  As he enters, he shakes the water from his hat.  He sees MacFarlane and go over to him quickly, excited and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor -- the little Marsh girl stood and walked -- really stood and walked --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane makes way for Fettes on the settle -- Fettes s down quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girl -- she couldn't walk far -- the muscles are too weak -- but she did stand and she took a step or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very excited) I know it -- I know it -- The moment I was rid of him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray -- I'm rid of him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes looks at him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guarding his thoughts) Just that -- just that -- I've managed to get him to leave Edinburgh -- he'll bother me no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rubs his hands together. The maidservant has returned with a bottle of brandy and glasses. MacFarlane pours one for himself and Fettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes picks up his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to a good riddance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that he's gone I'll be a new man, Fettes, and a better teacher. The doctors from my school will perform miracles --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and a party of five people dressed in roug mourning come in out of the weather. The maidservant, wit show of solicitude, ushers them to a table at the far end the inn, then crosses quickly to where the horse dealer i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sh-h-h! Still your song, lads -- the MacCreadys are here and they've come from burying the old woman in Glencorse Kirkyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop singing and look over with sympathetic glances the burial party.  MED. CLOSE SHOT - Fettes and MacFarlane.  MacFarlane look from the boys around the fire to the burial party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that, Fettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burial party -- poor people -- it's hard to bury a loved one on a rainy day when the churchyard is so cold and lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glencorse -- that's a lonely cemetery, Fettes, not a soul around for miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be thinking of that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tosh!  Fettes!  It's not their grief I'm worrying about -- I'm talking of our own end --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've no thought of going there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you think Gray was the only one who could handle a mattock and shovel?  I've had some practice in the art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting) You couldn't do that, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I pass up no opportunities, I've a whole course of lectures in mind for you fellows.  We'll need subjects to demonstrate. Come along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? I must have subjects. It's the only way I can teach. It's the only way you can learn. The stupidity of the people the idiocy of their laws will not stop no -- nor will they force me to deal with such reptilian creatures as Gray. We can do our own dirty work -- and we must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes shakes his head. MacFarlane starts for the door an after a little pause, Fettes rises and follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT. The thunder increases in volume throughout the scene.  In extreme b.g. two figures can be seen intermittently. CLOSE SHOT - grave. The headstone is brand new but the mo beneath it has been demolished, leaving a ragged gaping h A spade comes down into picture with vicious force.  As i raised with its burden of earth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphant) So we can't do without Mister Gray  - So I'd never be rid of him, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - MacFarlane and Fettes as they work over the grave. MacFarlane's spade thumps against wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps down into the grave, the CAMERA TILTING DOWN CUT OUT Fettes.  MacFarlane is levering up the edge of the co with his spade.  As the wood gives, there is a tremendous clap of thunder immediately overhead, followed by a solid deluge of rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT. The storm is raging. In the f.g. is MacFarlane's carriage, the horse tethered to the fence. Whickering, intensely nervous, he is looking o.s. toward cemetery. Shuffling footsteps come over shot and the hors fear increases.  MED. SHOT - at side of carriage is MacFarlane and Fettes into scene carrying a heavy burden, wrapped in canvas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarsely) Where shall we put it? In the back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No room there. We'll have to set it between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - The storm is continuing unabated. A narrow, twisting road runs down the hillside, and the terrain is desolate and rocky. Horse's hooves are heard and MacFarla carriage comes into the scene, going down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - MacFarlane. He is driving, his head thrust forward to see the road. The CAMERA PANS, VERY SLIGHTLY t show what is next to him; something wrapped in a thin she of canvas; something which sits limply; something which s the unmistakable shape of a human body beneath its coveri It is held by Fettes' hand which is just in shot. The CAM PANS again to show Fettes. His teeth are clenched; his ey closed.  MED. SHOT - showing both men and the thing between them. horse is trotting fast and as the carriage turns a bend, thing lunges heavily against MacFarlane's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely) Keep it off me, will you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - Still the storm - even fiercer. MacFarlane's carriage, the horse galloping, comes down the hill, swayi and lurching. The pace is much too fast for the going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. It is very dark. MacFarlane is hauling at the reins with all his strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savage) What's got into this animal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Fettes. He is still holding the thing o.s.  THREE SHOT. The carriage sways violently and the thing between the men, its outlines barely distinguishable, see to twist out of Fettes' grip. It sags against MacFarlane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forced to keep both hands on the reins, MacFarlane tries thrust the thing away with his shoulder. But it still kee falling against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Keep it off me, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes makes an effort to hold on to the corpse. MED. FULL SHOT -- the carriage going along the road; the horse proceeding at a hard trot. The hoof beats ring out rhythmically.  THREE SHOT -- PROCESS -- Fettes, MacFarlane and the corps The rhythmic hoof beats sound very loud as the two men dr on in silence. Fettes makes a desperate effort to hold th corpse away from MacFarlane, but it keeps bumping into th doctor.  Through the hoof beats and in the same rhythm co the voice of Gray on the sound track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll not get rid of me that way -- that way -- that way -- that way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacFarlane shakes his head as if to clear it of this remembered voice;  these well-remembered words.  CLOSE SHOT -- MacFarlane.  His eyes are wide with apprehension and fear.  He glances down at the wrapped co as it bumps against him. He draws away, shivering. Over t sound track Gray's voice still sounds beating on the ear the same rhythm as the hoofs on the road.  MacFarlane pul up on the reins.  THREE SHOT - as MacFarlane turns to Fettes the carriage c to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making an effort to arrive at speech) Fettes -- for Mercy's sake, let's have a light!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes looks over at his companion. He has never seen MacFarlane in this state before and the younger man is puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs over the sill into the roadway.  MED. FULL SHOT - the carriage as Fettes tries to strike a light in the pouring rain and howling wind. He finally ge taper going and touches it to the lamp wick. The lamp fla for a moment.  TWO SHOT -- MacFarlane and the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's changed!  I swear it! It's changed, Fettes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE SHOT - Fettes as he looks up puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changed? Changed, to what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE SHOT - MacFarlane and the corpse with Fettes a lower level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have that lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes undoes it from the dashboard and lifts it up over head to cast a light on the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking down at the bundle) This is not a woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter-of-factly) It was a woman when we put her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat wildly) Hold that lamp up -- I must see her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears open the sacking. ANOTHER ANGLE - CLOSE SHOT of Fettes.  He is looking up holding the lantern high over his head, but is unable to anything over the high dashboard except MacFarlane's face Suddenly, MacFarlane pulls back and on his face there is a look of anguish and terror that Fettes cries out in ala

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. MacFarlane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE SHOT - Now the face of the dead woman can be seen with MacFarlane looking down at it in horror as slowly it turns to the dark, well-moulded features and smooth-shave cheeks of the familiar countenance of Gray. A wild yell breaks from MacFarlane's lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray -- Gray --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT - the horse and carriage. The nervous hors bolts. Fettes tries to dodge out of the way. The lamp fal and breaks and in the darkness the carriage goes bounding past his and away. He stands looking after it, then break into a run, following the runaway. CLOSE SHOT - MacFarlane.  He is fighting to control the horse.  But, as the carriage rocks, the thing against his shoulder moves; either by reason of the violent motion or some frightful volition of its own.  The canvas wrapping slips, slides away and reveals again head and naked torso of Gray.  The pace increases even more. MacFarlane sees the dreadfu metamorphosis and a strangled cry breaks from his throat. The carriage sways again and the arms come free from the canvas. Another swerve, another lurch and they have falle limply around MacFarlane's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - a hairpin turn, with cliff-wall to one side, sheer drop to the other. The carriage, the horse beyond control, cannot take it at the speed. It strikes the clif wheel breaks loose, the braces tear apart, the horse staggers, runs on free, the carriage tilts sickeningly, stands on end, rolls over the edge and plunges down to destruction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fettes has managed to get the lamp going again and is run along the road, following the wheel tracks in the rain-so earth. He comes upon a bit of wreckage and stops. He list then walks over to the edge of the cliff. He holds his lantern well over the edge and peers down. Then he starts down the cliff side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT - Fettes as he scrambles down, holding the lantern at arm's length to protect it from the rough rock and the heather.  He comes to a slightly more level space stops. He looks down.  MED. SHOT - SHOOTING DOWNWARD FROM Fettes' viewpoint. MacFarlane's body, obviously without life, is lying flat its back, arms and legs outspread. And, lying against his chest, is something wrapped in canvas. The CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY DOWN UNTIL IT IS CLOSE, showing beyond all doubt that not only has the canvas never been disturbed, but also that it is the woman's body which it covers.
